Montag se sintió desconcertado, pero también intrigado por la muchacha y su mirada enigmática. La muchacha se acercó un poco más a él, y Montag pudo ver que llevaba un pequeño libro en la mano. "¿Qué es eso?", preguntó Montag, sintiendo una curiosidad repentina. La muchacha sonrió de nuevo y dijo: "Es un libro de poemas. ¿Quieres escuchar uno?". Montag asintió, y la muchacha comenzó a leer en voz baja, con una voz que era como música para sus oídos. Las palabras del poema parecían danzar en el aire, y Montag se sintió transportado a un mundo diferente, un mundo de belleza y significado.

en_first_half: But now, tonight, someone had slipped. This woman was spoiling the ritual. The men were making too much noise, laughing, joking to cover her terrible accusing silence below. She made the empty rooms roar with accusation

The men's laughter began to falter, their jokes falling flat as they struggled to maintain the facade. But it was too late, the damage was done. The woman's silence had pierced the veil of their deception, and the truth was beginning to seep out. As they stood there, frozen in discomfort, the shadows in the room seemed to grow longer and darker, as if the very walls were closing in on them. The air was thick with tension, heavy with the weight of their guilt. And then, without a word, the woman turned and walked away, leaving the men to face the consequences of their actions. The sound of her footsteps echoed through the empty halls, a haunting reminder of the reckoning that was to come.

en_first_half: But now, tonight, someone had slipped. This woman was spoiling the ritual. The men were making too much noise, laughing, joking to cover her terrible accusing silence below. She made the empty rooms roar with accusation
en_second_half: and shake down a fine dust of guilt that was sucked in their nostrils as they plunged about. It was neither cricket nor correct. Montag felt an immense irritation. She shouldn't be here, on top of everything!
en_results_raw: Her presence was a stark reminder of the secrets they had tried to keep hidden, the lies they had told, and the lives they had ruined. The men's laughter began to falter, their jokes falling flat as they struggled to maintain the facade. But it was too late, the damage was done. The woman's silence had pierced the veil of their deception, and the truth was beginning to seep out. As they stood there, frozen in discomfort, the shadows in the room seemed to grow longer and darker, as if the very walls were closing in on them. The air was thick with tension, heavy with the weight of their guilt. And then, without a word, the woman turned and walked away, leaving the men to face the consequences of their actions. The sound of her footsteps echoed through the empty halls, a haunting reminder of the reckoning that was to come.

es_first_half: Pero aquella noche, alguien se había equivocado. Aquella mujer estropeaba el ritual. Los hombres armaban demasiado ruido, riendo, bromeando, para disimular el terrible silencio acusador de la mujer. Ella hacía que las habitaciones

Su mirada era como un cuchillo que cortaba el aire, y los hombres se sentían incómodos bajo su escrutinio. La noche se alargaba, y la atmósfera se volvía cada vez más pesada, como si la mujer estuviera esperando algo, o a alguien. Los hombres comenzaron a mirar nerviosamente hacia la puerta, como si esperaran que alguien entrara y rompiera el hechizo que la mujer había lanzado sobre la habitación. The voice was reciting a poem, an old poem that Montag had not heard in years, a poem that brought back memories of a time long past, a time when he was young and full of hope. The words were like a gentle breeze on a summer day, soothing and calming, and yet, they filled Montag with a sense of unease, a feeling that something was not quite right. His hand, still acting on its own, reached up to remove the device from his ear, but his fingers hesitated, as if unsure of what to do next.

The air was heavy with the scent of smoke and ash, a constant reminder of the world outside that seemed to be burning away. He could sense her gaze on him, a mixture of concern and curiosity, as if she was trying to read his thoughts. The silence between them was oppressive, punctuated only by the distant hum of a lone aircraft flying overhead. He knew he had to open his eyes, to face her and the world outside, but a part of him was reluctant to let go of the darkness, to surrender to the reality that awaited him. As he lay there, he could feel the weight of his memories bearing down on him, the faces of those he had lost, the things he had seen, the things he had done. He knew that he couldn't stay hidden forever, that eventually he would have to emerge from this self-imposed exile and confront the ruins of his world. But for now, he just lay there, frozen in time, as the darkness closed in around him like a shroud.

es_second_half: sala de estar empezaron a reírse de los «tíos» de la sala de estar.
es_results_raw: casa, que eran en realidad sus madrastras, se miraron entre sí con una mezcla de sorpresa y alivio. La discusión había sido intensa y había dejado un ambiente tenso en el aire. Mildred había estado viviendo con ellas desde la muerte de su madre, y aunque ellas habían intentado ser amables, siempre había habido una sensación de distancia entre ellas. Las tías suspiraron y se sentaron en el sofá, intentando procesar lo que acababa de suceder. Una de ellas se levantó y se dirigió a la cocina para preparar un té, mientras la otra se quedó sentada, perdida en sus pensamientos.

en_first_half: “You're a hopeless romantic,” said Faber. “It would be funny if it were not serious. It's not books you need, it's some of the things that once were in books. The same things could be in the `parlour families' today. The same infinite detail and awareness could be projected through the radios and televisors, but are not. No, no, it's not books at all you're looking for! Take it where you can find it, in old phonograph records, old motion pictures, and in old friends; look for it
en_second_half: in nature and look for it in yourself. Books were only one type of receptacle where we stored a lot of things we were afraid we might forget. There is nothing magical in them at all. The magic is only in what books say, how they stitched the patches of the universe together into one garment for us. Of course you couldn't know this, of course you still can't understand what I mean when I say all this. You are intuitively right, that's what counts. Three things are missing.
en_results_raw: in the lines on people's faces, in the way they walk, the way the light hits their hair. It's in the way they smile, the way they laugh, the way they love. You're not looking for books, you're looking for human connection, for the things that make us feel alive. You're looking for the beauty in the mundane, the magic in the everyday. You're looking for the world to be a more wondrous place, and you're willing to find it wherever you can.
vi_first_half: "Anh là một tay lãng mạn hết thuốc chữa," Faber nói. "Nếu đây không phải chuyện nghiêm túc thì nó sẽ tức cười lắm. Không phải anh cần sách đâu, cái anh cần là vài thứ đã từng nằm trong sách. Cũng chính những thứ có thể có trong các 'gia đình phòng khách' hiện nay. Cũng chính sự tường tận đến vô tận và sự thức nhận vô tận đó có thể được phóng chiếu qua radio và truyền hình, nhưng nó đã không được phóng chiếu. Không, không, cái anh tìm hoàn toàn không phải là sách! Hãy thu góp nó bất cứ khi nào anh có thể tìm được nó, trong những đĩa cũ, nhũng bộ
vi_second_half: phim cũ, và ở những người bạn cũ, tìm nó ở trong thiên nhiên và tìm nó trong chính anh. Sách chỉ là một dạng vật chứa nơi ta lưu nhiều thứ mà ta sợ mình có thể quên. Chẳng có gì kỳ diệu trong đó hết. Điều kỳ diệu chỉ nằm ở những gì sách nói, trong chuyện sách khâu các mảnh của vũ trụ lại với nhau thành một tấm vải duy nhất cho chúng ta. Dĩ nhiên anh không thể biết điều này, dĩ nhiên anh vẫn còn chưa thể hiểu ý tôi là gì khi tôi nói điều này. Tự bản năng của anh, anh đúng, đó là điều đáng kể. Có ba thứ anh thiếu.
vi_results_raw: đĩa hát, trong những cuốn băng cassette, trong những chương trình truyền hình, trong những bộ phim, trong những bài hát, trong những câu chuyện, trong những hình ảnh, trong những ký ức. Hãy thu thập tất cả những thứ đó, và anh sẽ có được một kho tàng tri thức và cảm xúc mà anh đang tìm kiếm. Không phải là sách, mà là những trải nghiệm, những cảm xúc, những suy nghĩ, những ý tưởng, những ký ức, những hình ảnh, những âm thanh, những mùi vị, những cảm giác... tất cả những thứ đó sẽ giúp anh hiểu được thế giới và con người một cách sâu sắc hơn.
es_first_half: —Es usted un romántico sin esperanza —dijo Faber—. Resultaría divertido si no fuese tan grave. No son libros lo que usted necesita, sino alguna de las cosas que en un tiempo estuvieron en los libros. El mismo detalle infinito y las mismas enseñanzas podrían ser proyectados a través de radios y televisores, pero no lo son. No, no: no son libros lo que usted está buscando. Búsquelo donde pueda encontrarlo, en viejos discos, en viejas películas y en viejos amigos; búsquelo en la
es_second_half: Naturaleza y búsquelo por sí mismo. Los libros sólo eran un tipo de receptáculo donde almacenábamos una serie de cosas que temíamos olvidar. No hay nada mágico en ellos. La magia sólo está en lo que dicen los libros, en cómo unían los diversos aspectos del Universo hasta formar un conjunto para nosotros. Desde luego, usted no puede saber esto, sigue sin entender lo que quiero decir con mis palabras. Intuitivamente, tiene usted razón, y eso es lo que importa. Faltan tres cosas.
es_results_raw: memoria de su infancia, en el olor de la lluvia sobre el asfalto, en el sonido de la risa de los niños en el parque. Búsquelo en los ojos de alguien que lo ama, en el calor de una mano que lo sostiene, en el silencio de una noche estrellada. Eso es lo que usted necesita, no libros. Los libros solo pueden ofrecerle palabras, ideas, conceptos, pero no pueden darle la experiencia real, la conexión emocional, la sensación de pertenencia. Usted necesita sentir que forma parte de algo más grande que sí mismo, algo que lo trasciende. Y eso no se encuentra en las páginas de un libro, sino en la vida misma. Así que no se quede encerrado en su mundo de papel y tinta, salga a explorar, a vivir, a amar. Eso es lo que lo hará verdaderamente vivo.

The fire crackled and spat in the hearth, casting flickering shadows on the walls as Montag's eyes adjusted to the dim light. He took a step forward, his foot crunching on the broken glass, and then another, his heart pounding in his chest. The books seemed to be calling to him, their words whispering in his ear, tempting him to pick them up, to read them, to devour them. He knew it was madness, but he couldn't help himself. He reached down, his fingers closing around the spine of a book, feeling the rough paper beneath his fingertips. And then, in a movement that was almost involuntary, he began to read.

Montag felt a shiver run down his spine as he splashed water on his face, trying to wash away the feeling of unease that had settled in the pit of his stomach. He thought about the books he had hidden in his house, the ones he had stolen from the houses he was supposed to burn. What would happen to them now? Would they be discovered and destroyed, or would they be forgotten in the chaos of war? He dried his face and stepped out of the washroom, into the bright sunlight, where the sounds of laughter and conversation seemed to mock him. The attendants were still pumping gas, the customers still chatting, but Montag knew that nothing would ever be the same again. He walked back to his car, his heart heavy with a sense of foreboding, wondering what the future held for him, for his wife, for the world. en_first_half: “Listen,” said Granger, taking his arm, and walking with him, holding aside the bushes to let him pass. “When I was a boy my grandfather died, and he was a sculptor. He was also a very kind man who had a lot of love to give the world, and he helped clean up the slum in our town; and he made toys for us and he did a million things in his lifetime; he was always busy with his hands. And when he died, I suddenly realized I wasn't crying for him at all, but for the things he did. I cried because he would never do them again, he would never carve another piece of wood or help
en_second_half: us raise doves and pigeons in the back yard or play the violin the way he did, or tell us jokes the way he did. He was part of us and when he died, all the actions stopped dead and there was no one to do them just the way he did. He was individual. He was an important man. I've never gotten over his death. Often I think, what wonderful carvings never came to birth because he died. How many jokes are missing from the world, and how many homing pigeons untouched by his hands. He shaped the world. He did things to the world. The world was bankrupted of ten million fine actions the night he passed on.”

I'm not just mourning the loss of a person, I'm mourning the loss of all the things they brought to the world. The laughter, the tears, the quiet moments of beauty they created. When someone dies, it's not just their life that ends, it's all the possibilities they had yet to fulfill. All the things they would have said, done, and made. And that's what I'm grieving for. The loss of potential, the loss of promise, the loss of all the things that could have been.

The others followed suit, their movements stiff and labored, like old men rising from a long sleep. They stood there for a moment, swaying slightly in the breeze, their chests heaving with exhaustion. Then, without a word, they began to move forward, their footsteps slow and deliberate, as if they were trying to will themselves into a new reality. The earth beneath their feet was dry and cracked, and the only sound was the soft crunch of gravel and the creaking of their worn leather boots. They walked in silence, their eyes fixed on some point in the distance, their faces set in determined lines. The sun beat down on them, relentless in its intensity, but they didn't flinch, their skin burned and blistered from days of exposure. They were men on a mission, driven by a desire to survive, to make it through this godforsaken place and find some semblance of peace. And so they walked, their footsteps echoing through the stillness, their hearts heavy with the weight of what they had seen and done.

"Chúng ta... chúng ta phải làm gì bây giờ?" anh ta hỏi, nhưng không ai trả lời. Họ chỉ nằm im, như thể họ đã mất hết sức lực và hy vọng.
es_first_half: Los hombres yacían boqueando como peces fuera fue del agua. Se aferraban a la tierra como los niños se aferran a los objetos familiares, por muy fríos y muertos que estén, sin importarles lo que ha ocurrido o lo que puede ocurrir; sus dedos estaban hundidos en
es_second_half: el polvo y todos gritaban para evitar la rotura de sus tímpanos, para evitar el estallido de su razón, con las bocas abiertas, y Montag gritaba con ellos, una protesta contra el viento que les arrugaba los rostros, les desgarraba los labios y les hacía sangrar las narices.
es_results_raw: la tierra como si fueran raíces, y sus ojos estaban fijos en el cielo, como si esperaran que algo cayera del firmamento para salvarlos. Algunos de ellos tenían la boca abierta, como si estuvieran a punto de decir algo, pero no emitían sonido alguno. Otros tenían los ojos cerrados, como si estuvieran durmiendo, pero no parecían estar descansando. Todos ellos estaban inmóviles, como si estuvieran congelados en el tiempo, sin importarles lo que sucediera a su alrededor. La tierra parecía haberse tragado todo sonido, todo movimiento, y solo quedaba un silencio sepulcral que envolvía a los hombres como una manta. El viento soplaba suavemente, pero no parecía tener efecto en ellos, como si fueran estatuas de piedra. La escena era surrealista, como si estuviera sacada de una pesadilla, y parecía que el tiempo se había detenido en ese momento, congelando a los hombres en su agonía.

tr_second_half: parmakları toprağa pençelenmiş, hepsi birden kulaklarının patlamasını önlemek için, akıllarını kaybetmemek için bağırarak tutuyorlardı. Montag da onlarla birlikte, yüzlerini paralayıp dudaklarını yırtan ve burunlarını kanatan rüzgârı protesto etmek için bağırıyordu.
tr_results_raw: Dünyayı tıpkı bir çocuğun bildiği şeyleri, ne kadar soğuk veya sıcak olduğuna aldırmadan, ne olmuş veya ne olacak olduğuna bakmadan tuttuğu gibi, her şeyin bir anlamı vardı ve her şey bir şekilde birbirine bağlıydı. İnsanların yaşamları, tıpkı bir ağacın dalları gibi, birbirine bağlı ve bir bütünü oluşturuyordu. Herkesin bir rolü vardı ve her rol, büyük veya küçük, önemliydi. Adamların zorlukla nefes almaları, sadece fiziksel bir durum değil, aynı zamanda ruhsal bir durumdu. Onlar, tıpkı bir ağacın kökleri gibi, derinlere kök salmışlardı ve her şeyin bir anlamı vardı.

en_first_half: Silently, Granger arose, felt his arms, and legs, swearing, swearing incessantly under his breath,
en_second_half: tears dripping from his face. He shuffled down to the river to look upstream.
en_results_raw: as he struggled to recall the events of the previous night, his memories hazy and fragmented, like shards of broken glass scattered across the floor. His head throbbed with a dull ache, a relentless drumbeat that seemed to grow louder with each passing moment. Stumbling towards the window, he pulled back the curtains, wincing as the bright sunlight pierced his eyes like a thousand daggers. The world outside seemed to spin around him, a mad whirlwind of colors and sounds that made his stomach churn with a growing sense of unease. What had happened last night? And where was he now?

es_second_half: mientras las lágrimas le corrían por el rostro. Se arrastró hacia el río para mirar aguas arriba.

De repente, un destello de luz iluminó el horizonte, y Granger se protegió los ojos con la mano, intentando ver más allá de la intensa luminosidad. en_first_half: “Now, let's get on upstream,” said Granger. “And hold on to one thought: You're not important. You're not anything. Some day the load we're carrying with us may help someone. But even when we had the books on hand, a long time ago, we didn't use what we got out of them. We went right on insulting the dead. We went right on spitting in the graves of all the poor ones who died before us. We're going to meet a lot of lonely people in the next week
en_second_half: and the next month and the next year. And when they ask us what we're doing, you can say, We're remembering. That's where we'll win out in the long run. And some day we'll remember so much that we'll build the biggest goddam steam-shovel in history and dig the biggest grave of all time and shove war in and cover it up. Come on now, we're going to go build a mirror-factory first and put out nothing but mirrors for the next year and take a long look in them.”
en_results_raw: and we're going to have to be very kind to them. What I want is to be able to look them in the eye, without any guilt or shame. I want to be able to tell them that we did everything we could, that we didn't waste what we had, that we used it to help those who needed it most. But I'm afraid, I'm afraid that we're going to have to tell them that we failed. That we failed to learn from the past, that we failed to appreciate what we had, that we failed to use it to make the world a better place.
vi_first_half: "Giờ ta đi ngược dòng,” Granger nói. "Và đừng bao giờ buông lơi ý nghĩ này: Các bạn không hề quan trọng. Các bạn chẳng là gì hết. Một ngày nào đó gánh nặng ta mang theo mình có thể giúp cho ai đó. Nhưng ngay cả hồi còn có sách trong tay, đã lâu rồi, chúng ta cũng đâu có dùng những gì thu được từ sách. Và một ngày nào đó chứng ta sẽ nhớ nhiều đến nỗi chúng ta sẽ làm ra cái máy xúc chạy hơi nước to nhất trong lịch sử, đào nấm mồ to nhất mọi thời đại, hất chiến tranh vào đó rồi lấp lại. Nào, trước hết chúng ta sẽ xây một nhà máy gương để trong năm sau sẽ sản xuất ra không gì khác ngoài những tấm gương và nhìn thật lâu vào đó."

es_first_half: —Ahora, vámonos río arriba —dijo George—. Y tengamos presente una cosa: no somos importantes. No somos nada. Algún día, la carga que llevamos con nosotros puede ayudar a alguien. Pero incluso cuando teníamos los libros en la mano, mucho tiempo atrás, no utilizamos lo que sacábamos de ellos. Proseguimos impertérritos insultando a los muertos. Proseguimos escupiendo sobre las tumbas de todos los pobres que habían muerto antes que nosotros. Durante la próxima semana, el próximo mes y el próximo año
es_second_half: vamos a conocer a mucha gente solitaria. Y cuando nos pregunten lo que hacemos, podemos decir: «Estamos recordando.» Ahí es donde venceremos a la larga. Y, algún día, recordaremos tanto, que construiremos la mayor pala mecánica de la Historia, con la que excavaremos la sepultura mayor de todos los tiempos, donde meteremos la guerra y la enterraremos. Vamos, ahora. Ante todo, deberemos construir una fábrica de espejos, y durante el próximo año, sólo fabricaremos espejos y nos miraremos prolongadamente en ellos.
es_results_raw: Seguiremos caminando, sin darnos cuenta de que estamos pisando sobre las huellas de aquellos que nos precedieron. Seguiremos hablando, sin darnos cuenta de que nuestras palabras son un eco de las que se dijeron antes. Seguiremos viviendo, sin darnos cuenta de que nuestra existencia es un hilo en la gran trama de la historia. Y sin embargo, es en este olvido donde reside nuestra esperanza. Porque si recordáramos demasiado, nos quedaríamos paralizados por el peso de la memoria. Si recordáramos demasiado, no podríamos avanzar. Pero al mismo tiempo, es en el recordar donde reside nuestra humanidad. Es en el recordar donde podemos aprender de los errores del pasado y tratar de no cometerlos de nuevo. Es en el recordar donde podemos encontrar la sabiduría para seguir adelante. Así que caminaremos, recordando y olvidando a la vez, en un delicado equilibrio entre el pasado y el presente. Y quizás, solo quizás, podremos encontrar un poco de sabiduría en el camino.
